content: Find the inverses of the matrices in this Exercise \[\begin{bmatrix}8 & 6 \5 & 4\end{bmatrix}\].

In this exercise, find the vector $\mathbf{x}$ determined by the given coordinate vector $\left[ \mathbf{x} ight]_B$ and the given basis $B$.  egin{enumerate}  \item   Let the basis $B = \left\{    egin{bmatrix}  1 \  1  \end{bmatrix},  \begin{bmatrix}  2 \  -1  \end{bmatrix}  ight\}$, and the coordinate vector $\left[ \mathbf{x} ight]_B =    egin{bmatrix}  3 \  2  \end{bmatrix}$. Find the vector $\mathbf{x}$.\end{enumerate}.
Find an LU factorization of the matrix\[\begin{bmatrix}6 & 9 \4 & 5\end{bmatrix}\].
Let A and D be defined as follows:\[A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 1 & 1 \1 & 2 & 3 \1 & 4 & 5\end{bmatrix},\quad D =  egin{bmatrix}2 & 0 & 0 \0 & 3 & 0 \0 & 0 & 5\end{bmatrix}\]Compute AD and DA.
Let \[A = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 5 \-3 & 1\end{bmatrix},\quad B =  egin{bmatrix}4 & -5 \3 & k\end{bmatrix}\]What value(s) of k, if any, will make AB = BA?
Let \[A = \begin{bmatrix}3 & -6 \-1 & 2\end{bmatrix}\]Construct a \( 2 \times 2 \) matrix \( B \) such that \( AB \) is the zero matrix. Use two different nonzero columns for \( B \).

Let \( r_1, \dots, r_p \) be vectors in \( \mathbb{R}^n \), and let \( Q \) be an \( m 	imes n \) matrix. Write the matrix \[\left[ Q r_1 \; Q r_2 \; \dots \; Q r_p ight]\]as a product of two matrices (neither of which is an identity matrix).
Construct a \( 4 	imes 3 \) matrix with rank 1.

In the Exercise, find a basis for the subspace spanned by the given vectors. What is the dimension of the subspace?\[\mathbf{v}_1 =  egin{bmatrix} 1 \ -3 \ 2 \ -4 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{v}_2 =  egin{bmatrix} -3 \ 9 \ -6 \ 12 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{v}_3 =  egin{bmatrix} 2 \ -1 \ 4 \ 2 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{v}_4 =  egin{bmatrix} -4 \ 5 \ -3 \ 7 \end{bmatrix}\].

Display a matrix $A$ and an echelon form of $A$. Find bases for $	ext{Col } A$ and $	ext{Nul } A$, and then state the dimensions of these subspaces.\[ \quad A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & -3 & 2 & -4 \-3 & 9 & -1 & 5 \2 & -6 & 4 & -3 \-4 & 12 & 2 & 7 \\end{bmatrix}, \quad\]\[\text{Echelon form of } A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & -3 & 2 & -4 \0 & 0 & 5 & -7 \0 & 0 & 0 & 5 \0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\end{bmatrix}\].

Find the eigenvalues of the matrices in this exercise.\[ \quad \begin{bmatrix}0 & 0 & 0 \0 & 2 & 5 \0 & 0 & 1 \\end{bmatrix}\].
Find the characteristic polynomial and the eigenvalues of the matrix in:\[\begin{bmatrix}2 & 1 \-1 & 4 \\end{bmatrix}\].

In this exercise, find a basis for the eigenspace corresponding to each listed eigenvalue.\[A = \begin{bmatrix}3 & 0 & 2 & 0 \1 & 3 & 1 & 0 \0 & 1 & 1 & 0 \0 & 0 & 0 & 4 \\end{bmatrix}, \quad \lambda = 4\].

It can be shown that the algebraic multiplicity of an eigenvalue is always greater than or equal to the dimension of the eigenspace corresponding to $\lambda$. Find $h$ in the matrix $A$ below such that the eigenspace for $\lambda=5$ is two-dimensional:\[A = \begin{bmatrix}5 & -2 & 6 & -1 \0 & 3 & h & 0 \0 & 0 & 5 & 4 \0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \\end{bmatrix}\].

find an invertible matrix $P$ and a matrix $C$ of the form $\begin{pmatrix} a & b \ -b & a \end{pmatrix}$ such that the given matrix has the form $A = PCP^{-1}$. \A= $ egin{pmatrix} 1 & -2 \ 1 & 3 \end{pmatrix}$.

Assume the mapping $T \colon \mathbb{P}_2 	o \mathbb{P}_2$ defined by\[T(a_0 + a_1t + a_2t^2) = 3a_0 + (5a_0 - 2a_1)t + (4a_1 + a_2)t^2\]is linear. Find the matrix representation of $T$ relative to the basis $\mathcal{B} = \{1, t, t^2\}$.

Define $T \colon \mathbb{P}_2 	o \mathbb{R}^3$ by\[T(p) =  egin{bmatrix}p(-1) \p(0) \p(1) \\end{bmatrix}.\]a. Find the image under $T$ of $p(t) = 5 + 3t$. \b. Find the matrix for $T$ relative to the basis $\{1, t, t^2\}$ for$\mathbb{P}_2$ and the standard basis for $\mathbb{R}^3$.

In this exercise, define $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ by $T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x}$. Find a basis $\mathcal{B}$ for $\mathbb{R}^2$ with the property that $[T]_{\mathcal{B}}$ is diagonal.\[\quad A =  egin{bmatrix}0 & 1 \-3 & 4 \\end{bmatrix}\].

Let \[A =  egin{bmatrix}1 & 1 \-1 & 3 \\end{bmatrix}\quad \text{and} \quad \mathcal{B} = \{\mathbf{b}_1, \mathbf{b}_2\}, \quad \text{for} \quad \mathbf{b}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \mathbf{b}_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \ 4 \end{bmatrix}.\]Define $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ by $T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x}$.Find the $\mathcal{B}$-matrix for $T$.

Let \[A = \begin{bmatrix}0.6 & 0.3 \0.4 & 0.7 \\end{bmatrix}, \quad\mathbf{v}_1 = \begin{bmatrix}3/7 \4/7 \\end{bmatrix}, \quad\mathbf{x}_0 =  egin{bmatrix}0.5 \0.5 \\end{bmatrix}.\][Note: $A$ is the stochastic matrix] a. Find a basis for $\mathbb{R}^2$ consisting of $\mathbf{v}_1$ and another eigenvector $\mathbf{v}_2$ of $A$.

In this exercise, with $T$ defined by $T(\mathbf{x}) = A\mathbf{x}$, find a vector $\mathbf{x}$ whose image under $T$ is $\mathbf{b}$, and determine whether $\mathbf{x}$ is unique.\[\quad A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & -2 \-2 & 1 & 6 \3 & -2 & -5 \\end{bmatrix}, \quad\mathbf{b} = \begin{bmatrix}-1 \7 \-3 \\end{bmatrix}\].

In this exercise, assume that $T$ is a linear transformation. Find the standard matrix of $T$. \T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2 \text{ rotates points (about the origin)} \\text{through } \frac{3\pi}{2} \text{ radians (counterclockwise).}

Let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation that maps\[\mathbf{u} = \begin{bmatrix} 5 \ 2 \end{bmatrix} \text{ into } \begin{bmatrix} 2 \ 1 \end{bmatrix}\]and maps\[\mathbf{v} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \ 3 \end{bmatrix} \text{ into } \begin{bmatrix} -1 \ 3 \end{bmatrix}.\]Use the fact that $T$ is linear to find the images under $T$ of $3\mathbf{u}$, $2\mathbf{v}$, and $3\mathbf{u} + 2\mathbf{v}$.

For this exercise, find all $\mathbf{x}$ in $\mathbb{R}^4$ that are mapped into the zero vector by the transformation $\mathbf{x} \mapsto A\mathbf{x}$ for the given matrix $A$.\[\quad A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & -4 & 7 & -5 \0 & 1 & -4 & 3 \2 & -6 & 6 & -4 \\end{bmatrix}\].

fill in the missing entries of the matrix, assuming that the equation holds for all values of the variables.\[\quad \begin{bmatrix}\bullet & \bullet & \bullet \\bullet & \bullet & \bullet \\bullet & \bullet & \bullet \\end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix}x_1 \x_2 \x_3 \\end{bmatrix}= \begin{bmatrix}3x_1 - 2x_3 \4x_1 \x_1 - x_2 + x_3 \\end{bmatrix}\].

In this exercise, show that $T$ is a linear transformation by finding a matrix that implements the mapping. Note that $x_1, x_2, \dots$ are not vectors but are entries in vectors.\[\quad T(x_1, x_2, x_3, x_4) = (0, x_1 + x_2, x_2 + x_3, x_3 + x_4)\].

Let \[\mathbf{e}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \ 0 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{e}_2 =  egin{bmatrix} 0 \ 1 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{y}_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \ 5 \end{bmatrix}, \quad 	ext{and} \quad \mathbf{y}_2 =  egin{bmatrix} -1 \ 6 \end{bmatrix},\]and let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation that maps $\mathbf{e}_1$ into $\mathbf{y}_1$ and maps $\mathbf{e}_2$ into $\mathbf{y}_2$. Find the images of \[\begin{bmatrix} 5 \ -3 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \ x_2 \end{bmatrix}.\].

Let \[\mathbf{x} =  egin{bmatrix} x_1 \ x_2 \end{bmatrix}, \quad \mathbf{v}_1 =  egin{bmatrix} -2 \ 5 \end{bmatrix}, \quad 	ext{and} \quad \mathbf{v}_2 =  egin{bmatrix} 7 \ -3 \end{bmatrix},\]and let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation that maps $\mathbf{x}$ into $x_1\mathbf{v}_1 + x_2\mathbf{v}_2$. Find a matrix $A$ such that $T(\mathbf{x})$ is $A\mathbf{x}$ for each $\mathbf{x}$.
Let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^2$ be a linear transformation such that\[T(x_1, x_2) = (x_1 + x_2, 4x_1 + 5x_2).\]Find $\mathbf{x}$ such that $T(\mathbf{x}) = (3, 8)$.
Let $T \colon \mathbb{R}^2 \to \mathbb{R}^3$ be a linear transformation such that\[T(x_1, x_2) = (x_1 - 2x_2, -x_1 + 3x_2, 3x_1 - 2x_2).\]Find $\mathbf{x}$ such that $T(\mathbf{x}) = (-1, 4, 9)$.
